discussion.content:
D.

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/cloningavolume.htm

Because the clone is a copy of the source volume it is the same size as the source volume unless you specify a larger volume size when you create the clone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true about cloning a volume in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Block Volume service?

choices.D: You can change the block volume size when cloning a volume.
choices.C: You need to detach a volume before cloning it.
choices.B: You can clone a volume to another region.
choices.A: Creating a clone takes longer than creating a backup of a volume.

questions.question_text: Which statement is TRUE about restoring a volume from a block volume backup in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Block Volume service?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You can restore a block volume backup to a larger volume size.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/restoringavolumefromabackup.htm#:~:text=You%20can%20restore%20a%20block,you%20cannot%20decrease%20the%20size.

choices.A: You can only restore a volume to the same availability domain in which the original block volume resides.
choices.B: You can restore a volume from any full volume backup but not from an incremental backup.
choices.D: You can restore a block volume backup to a larger volume size.
choices.C: You can restore only one volume from a manual block volume backup.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Per https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/compute-cloud-at-customer/topics/block/assinging-a-backup-policy-to-a-volume-or-volume-group.htm, a volume or volume group can have only one backup policy assigned

In my understanding, when you create a volume group, you can add multiples boot and block volumes, and then associate it just one policy backup. I've implemented in my tenants option described in C option. Someone with a different experience?

questions.question_text:
You are responsible for creating and maintaining an enterprise application that consists of multiple storage volumes across multiple compute instances in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI).
The storage volumes include boot volumes and block volumes for your data storage. You need to create a backup for the boot volumes that will be done daily and a backup for the block volumes that will be done every six hours.
How can you meet this requirement?

choices.D: Create on-demand full backups of block volumes, and create custom images from the boot volumes. Use a function to run at a specific time to start the backup process.
choices.B: Create clones of all boot volumes and block volumes one at a time.
choices.C: Create two volume groups for grouping boot volumes and block volumes separately. Create two custom backup policies as per requirement.
choices.A: Group both boot volumes and block volumes in a volume group and create volume group backups.

choices.B: You need to provide your OCI credentials to the partner company.
choices.D: You cannot edit a pre-authenticated request.
choices.C: Pre-authenticated requests can be used to delete buckets or objects.
choices.A: Deleting a pre-authenticated request does not revoke user access to the associated bucket or object.

questions.question_text:
You have objects stored in an OCI Object Storage bucket that you want to share with a partner company. You decide to use pre-authenticated requests to grant access to the objects.
Which statement is true about pre-authenticated requests?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D "You can't edit a pre-authenticated request. To change user access options or enable object listing in response to changing requirements, you must create a new pre-authenticated request." 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingpreauthenticatedrequests.htm
D is correct. you cannot edit a pre-authenticated request.

you would need at least 4 reservations (2 for VM.Standard2.2 and 2 for VM.Standard.E4.Flex) to meet the requirement of having capacity reservations for the specified instances in at least two Availability Domains.

The correct answer is A. Four.

questions.question_text:
You are launching a new project in the US West (Phoenix) region. You would like to reserve the compute capacity mentioned below so that the capacity is available for your workloads when you need it.
10 VM.Standard2.2 Instances
6 VM.Standard.E4.Flex Instances
The project also requires you to be mindful about high availability and place the instances in at least two Availability Domains.
At a bare minimum, how many capacity reservations would you create to meet this requirement?
